dataSet.title: Colour drawings of automobile speedometers from 1904-2007
dataSet.description:
Automobile speedometers appeared at the turn of the century and although many were at first similar in design to clocks, they soon developed their own pattern as a result of greater understanding of drivers’ needs, speed limits, the practicalities of fitting the dial onto the dashboard, style preferences and changes in technology. In developing dials, designers have experimented with different positions of reference points; dial shapes; analogue and digital read-outs; the number and shapes of scale marks; multiple and reconfigurable scales; increments, style and placement of numbers; needle designs; moving versus stationary scales; and colours.
The researcher selected examples based upon their historical significance and differences between dials. The collection consists of computer drawn examples of circular dials from as early as 1904 through to 2007, linear dials from the 1950s through I970s. The collection also includes a taxonomy of analogue dial features which include dial shapes, reference point placements, scales, scale marks, fonts, number placements, and needles.

relatedResearchOutput.name: The development of automobile speedometer dials: A balance of ergonomics and style, regulation and power

dataSet.title: Australia and New Zealand gamers research database
dataSet.description: Demographic, behavioural and attitudinal data of people who play computer games compared to people who do not. An audience study of 1200 households in Australia and 800 households in New Zealand. The data was collected in 2009.

relatedResearchOutput.name: Case study: Australia's computer games audience and restrictive ratings system

dataSet.title: Data from eight studies on evaluating brand extensions
dataSet.description:
Eight data sets are made available by: Aaker and Keller (1990), Sunde and Brodie (1993), Alexandre-Bourhis (1994), Nijssen and Hartman (1994), Holden and Barwise (1995), and Bottomley and Doyle (1996) examining the way in which consumers evaluate brand extensions. However, because Holden and Barwise collected three sets of data, their data sets are referred to by the university where the data were collected (i.e., London Business School [LBS], ESSEC in France, and University of Illinois in the United States). The data is available in xls and SPSS formats.
Data includes: brand extention name, quality, complementary, substitute, transfer, quality extension, try, usage and researchers name.

dataSet.title: Triathlon in Australia Open Data Set
dataSet.description:
Dr Hunt first started researching and compiling her book Multisport dreaming: The Foundations of triathlon in Australia in 2010. The book was launched at Bond University 20 June 2014 and chronicles the evolution of triathlon in Australia which is full of triumphs and ‘firsts’. Australia hosted the first Olympic triathlon, the first fully professional race series and has produced wave after wave of age group and elite International Triathlon Union (ITU) and Ironman world champions.
Over the course of the project Dr Hunt conducted over 200 interviews and gathered a unique set of data on the topic in the form of audio and video interviews, newsletters, articles, race results, administrative records and photos from across Australia.
Data may be entirely openly accessible or partially available depending on copyright or licencing restrictions.
This project is supported by the Australian National Data Service (ANDS). ANDS is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy Program.
See the data set described in Research Data Australia.

relatedDataSets.name: Triathlon in Australia - Gold Coast Case Study
Triathlon in Australian Survey Template Collection

relatedResearchOutput.name: Multisport dreaming: The foundations of triathlon in Australia

link.description: The items in this dataset are made available under a CC BY 4.0 licence

dataSet.title: David Priestley Image Gallery
dataSet.description:
Founding editor of Australasian Cycling and freelance journalist, Victorian-based David Priestley was quick to recognize the marketing benefits of including triathlon news in his newspaper style publication. The re-named periodical Australasian Cycling and Triathlon News ran for approximately a decade from 1982/83 to 1992/1993. Priestley sold it in 1991 but continued to write and produce photographic images for the paper until it folded a year or so later. In the process Priestley amassed a large collection of photographic images – most taken by himself – that document the rapid evolution of triathlon from a chaotic and dangerous challenge for multisport extremists to an organized, commercialized Olympic sport. While Priestley labeled most photographs in the collection, the information is often incomplete or inaccurate. Many early photographs reflect Priestley’s Victorian background, featuring athletes and events in that state.
The items in this dataset are made available under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) licence.

relatedDataSets.name: Triathlon in Australia Open Data Set

link.description: Link to the David Priestley Image Gallery

dataSet.title: Greg Reddan Image Gallery
dataSet.description:
Greg Reddan was involved in several sports before joining the historic Sydney Freshwater Surf Lifesaving club in 1962. He won the first Australian aquathon (5km run, 800m swim) in 1980 and finished fifth in the 1981 Gold Coast Marathon in a time of 2 hours 34 min. In October 1981 Reddan, aged 35, used his endurance background in the inaugural Sutherland Shire Tri-Marathon to overhaul Rick Parkes in the final bike leg to win his first triathlon. A similar scenario occurred a month later in the Nautilus Triathlon in Melbourne during the final run leg. The prize was a trip to compete in the ‘Hawaiian Ironman’, which Reddan considered to be a race for ‘loonies’. With limited bike training he finished seventh at Kona (his third triathlon) in February 1982 and became the first Australian to complete the iconic event.
Dr Reddan retired in 2002, after 21 years of competition, with a win in the 55-59 year age group at the Australian championships. Until recently he competed in ocean swims and masters surf competitions and is a Senior Lecturer in Sports Coaching at Griffith University, Queensland.
Excerpt from: Hunt, J (2014) Multisport dreaming: The foundations of triathlon in Australia, p.13.
The items in this dataset are made available under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) licence.

relatedDataSets.name: Triathlon in Australia Open Data Set

dataSet.title: Louise Mackinlay Image Gallery
dataSet.description:
It was a series of wins in quick succession that brought Mackinlay to the attention of the broader triathlon community. In January 1986, she won the MacMasters Beach Triathlon, the ACT Sri Chinmoy Triathlon and the Aquatic Festival Triathlon. Later in the year Mackinlay finished in the top ten of the 1986 IRONMAN Hawaii, and placed first in her age group. It was by far the best performance by an Australian woman at the iconic event since its inception. She followed up her debut IRONMAN performance with a win at the ultra distance Great Lakes International Triathlon. Off the back of this string of successes, Mackinlay was voted 1987 Triathlete of the Year. Louise went on to win the IRONMAN Australia three years in a row (from 1987-1989).
Excerpt from: Hunt, J (2014) Multisport dreaming: The foundations of triathlon in Australia, p.77.
Louise was inducted into the Triathlon Australia Hall of Fame in 2014: Read more about her extraordinary performances on the Triathlon Australia website.

dataSet.title: Bob Telfer Collection
dataSet.description:
Bob Telfer is a life member of the Cronulla Tri Club. His success in the sport of triathlon has lead Triathlon Australia to include him in their ’Hall of Fame,’ which is an honour awarded to those whose triathlon careers are distinguished by a high level of sporting performance.
Bob’s major achievements are: > 1998 – 8th position at the Sunrice St George Triterium > 1992 – winner of the Age Title of the World Ironman, an annual competition held in Kona, Hawaii > 1987 – 2nd position at the 2nd Great Lakes International Triathlon, held in Foster > 1985 – 2nd position in the in the Benefit Planners Sydney Triathlon (half Ironman), held in Narrabeen
Bob’s achievements have been an inspiration to other athletes, especially coming 2nd place in the 1987 Foster triathlon, at age 42. He has been described by various people as humble and as a gentleman. Ann Telfer, Bob's wife, has also been involved in triathlon and was one of NSW’s top female triathletes during the 1980s.
The items in this dataset are made available under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) licence.

relatedDataSets.name: Triathlon in Australia Open Data Set

dataSet.title: Appendices for 'A systematic review, meta-analysis and meta-regression of the prevalence of protein-energy malnutrition: associations with geographical region and sex'
dataSet.description:
Appendix 1: Search strategy implemented across six electronic databases and results of total records retrieved
Appendix 2: Data_Extraction_PEM_Community (separate data set)
Appendix 3: Generalised representation of the percent pooled prevalence of malnutrition in community-dwelling older adults according to geographical region as reported in Table 1. All data are percentages.

relatedResearchOutput.name: A systematic review, meta-analysis and meta-regression of the prevalence of protein-energy malnutrition: associations with geographical region and sex
